Great idea!

"Although a series can change as it creatively finds itself, TV directors agree that a pilot often is the best representation of a show. Its where you really establish tone, says Tucker Gates, who directed the Bates Motel (A E) pilot. You establish look. You establish performance and characters and the rhythms of the show. Its a chance for a director to come in and create that. Thats why those episodes are nominated more than others."
http://variety.com/2013/tv/awards/pilot-directors-soar-but-regular-episodes-do-heavy-lifting-1200497393/

The Director helps to establish a visual language for individual episodes and for the series as a whole. The Pilot establishes the look and feel of a series and early episodes have continue that work. It is true that new directors can make some tweaks here and there.

The director of the pilot has a huge influence of the complete style of a tv show. All following directors are "looking" at how he did the pilot and they try to recreate it so it will follow the same style.

Yeah I agree, the pilot was fantastic the following episodes were mediocre at best. The director of the pilot should have directed the whole season (It was the director of the original girl with the dragon tatoo)

It was on a Sitcom called Undatetable. It airs on NBC and is created by the same guy who made Scrubs and Cougar Town. Last night had a lot of cameos included Ed Sheeran because it was a live episode! It was really fun seeing the cast (which has a great chemistry) improvising some lines and trying not to laugh. The meta humor was also fantastic.
